content.$t: paragraph-title: Two Cultures, paragraph-text: Viewing course offerings in our dataset, we see a variety of phenomena: course offerings rise and fall; changes occur in the frequency of offerings; some course last for decades, while others are only offered once. These phenomena can be the effects of many causes: in addition to progress in fields and shifts in teaching emphasis, change in administrative practices and technology frameworks, and departmental personnel, often having little to do with intellectual or disciplinary history. Nonetheless, some remarkable patterns are discernible, suggesting contrasts between C. P. Snow's two cultures: the sciences and the humanities.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Viewing course offerings in our dataset, we see a variety of phenomena: course offerings rise and fall; changes occur in the frequency of offerings; some course last for decades, while others are only offered once. These phenomena can be the effects of many causes: in addition to progress in fields and shifts in teaching emphasis, change in administrative practices and technology frameworks, and departmental personnel, often having little to do with intellectual or disciplinary history. Nonetheless, some remarkable patterns are discernible, suggesting contrasts between C. P. Snow's two cultures: the sciences and the humanities.

content.$t: image-link: ./data/story-two-cultures/media/TheTwoCultures.jpg, image-subline: First edition of the book "The Two Cultures and the Scientific Revolution" (1959).

gsx$image-subline.$t: First edition of the book "The Two Cultures and the Scientific Revolution" (1959).

content.$t: paragraph-title: Computer Science, paragraph-text: # Why the lack in Lecture courses?, snippet-text: Lecture courses in computer programming suddenly disappear between 1995 and 2000, only to steadily build again in number through the present time. Where did those lecture classes go?, snippet-pos: 115691, 1998

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: # Why the lack in Lecture courses?

gsx$snippet-text.$t: Lecture courses in computer programming suddenly disappear between 1995 and 2000, only to steadily build again in number through the present time. Where did those lecture classes go?

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: # Exceptional consistency, with offerings conserved over years across many types of courses, is a hallmark of computer science and other scientific disciplines.

content.$t: paragraph-text: Aside from the gap in lecture classes ca. 1997-2001, Computer Science is a remarkably stable department, with many classes that have been taught for over 20 years. What are we seeing here? One hypothesis: sciences define themselves by methods and topics, which (as Thomas Kuhn argued) shift paradigmatically. Courses are the boxes that hold them and keep these paradigms safe. Within courses, content (methods and topics, their names and relations) may change, but the external character of the boxes—the paradigms that shape the discipline—is conserved over time.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Aside from the gap in lecture classes ca. 1997-2001, Computer Science is a remarkably stable department, with many classes that have been taught for over 20 years. What are we seeing here? One hypothesis: sciences define themselves by methods and topics, which (as Thomas Kuhn argued) shift paradigmatically. Courses are the boxes that hold them and keep these paradigms safe. Within courses, content (methods and topics, their names and relations) may change, but the external character of the boxes—the paradigms that shape the discipline—is conserved over time.

content.$t: paragraph-title: History, paragraph-text: On the other extreme is history. The past is unchangeable—and yet its interpretation varies widely and is changing continually. We see this churn and change in the course offerings of the history department over time. There is a constant ripple of disruption and reconfiguration. Notably, this variability exists not only among courses but course types, with the balance of departmental offerings across lecture, seminar, and other modes changing markedly throughout the period for which we have data., data-title: History, data-link: ./data/story-two-cultures/HISTORY_1990_2020.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: On the other extreme is history. The past is unchangeable—and yet its interpretation varies widely and is changing continually. We see this churn and change in the course offerings of the history department over time. There is a constant ripple of disruption and reconfiguration. Notably, this variability exists not only among courses but course types, with the balance of departmental offerings across lecture, seminar, and other modes changing markedly throughout the period for which we have data.

gsx$image-subline.$t: Areas with a scattering of unique, one-time course offerings (indicated in green) show times of particular churn and transformation in curriculum.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: As we just saw the entire department of Computer Science had 20 one time classes during 1990 and 2020. In the same timeframe History had 325 of such classes. This distinction between the two departments is only one indication of a larger pattern in which classes are more frequently exchanged.

gsx$snippet-text.$t: Especially since 2014 the History department introduced a set of independent classes throughout the components of seminars, lectures and conference courses.

content.$t: paragraph-text: # A block of courses like this stands out for its continuity. The lecture courses clustered here consist of a set of offerings on the history of the US, defined by era, and two courses on Korea and Ukraine in the modern era., snippet-highlight: 142710,142846,148090,142708,142713,142712

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: # A block of courses like this stands out for its continuity. The lecture courses clustered here consist of a set of offerings on the history of the US, defined by era, and two courses on Korea and Ukraine in the modern era.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: This pattern is not restricted to Computer Science and History, but something we find repeated throughout the curriculum. Let’s look at more departments that fall into the category of science.

content.$t:
paragraph-title: Physics, paragraph-text: On the website of Harvards Physics department is says: ‘Physics was a required course at Harvard College by 1642. At that time, the text was by Aristotle.’ The contemporary physics department is most probably not teaching too much about Aristotle. But with ten Nobel Prize winners it is a well established department within Harvard and one of the top-ranked physics departments in the nation.
https://www.physics.harvard.edu/about/history

# Continuous patterns in thesis research are especially notable in sciences, distinct from humanities thesis-research units, which tend to be generic. Individual theses in the humanities seem to take on highly distinct topics, while science thesis activity falls within topical "buckets" that are rigorously defined by the field.

There are distinct regions where green-visualized courses cluster, indicating courses offered a single time and not repeated. Do these clusters represent eras of experiment and discovery in the English Department, new faculty hires, or changes in administration?
New courses arrive in English, semester by semester, in distinct waves, most of them lasting three or four years before winking out and only got thought twice. 613 classes follow this pattern.

content.$t: paragraph-title: Hybrid Disciplines, paragraph-text: Not all departments can be easily placed into the distinction of humanities and sciences. There are a handful of branches within the University which lie in-between the two cultures. Let us also look at the patterns of some of these departments., data-title: Architecture, data-link: ./data/story-two-cultures/ARCHITECTURE_1990_2020.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Not all departments can be easily placed into the distinction of humanities and sciences. There are a handful of branches within the University which lie in-between the two cultures. Let us also look at the patterns of some of these departments.

content.$t: paragraph-title: Architecture, paragraph-text: Architecture, a hybrid discipline combining aesthetics and engineering, is a distinctive case. Studio courses, which serve as the basis of training for architectural practice, show notable conservatism over time, while seminar and lecture offerings vary like humanities departments. It's in the latter courses that architects encounter topics that enrich style and sensibility, and learn to approach their work as historically-informed artists and critical interpreters of human uses of the built environment.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Architecture, a hybrid discipline combining aesthetics and engineering, is a distinctive case. Studio courses, which serve as the basis of training for architectural practice, show notable conservatism over time, while seminar and lecture offerings vary like humanities departments. It's in the latter courses that architects encounter topics that enrich style and sensibility, and learn to approach their work as historically-informed artists and critical interpreters of human uses of the built environment.

Unique and new courses pop up throughout the period of our data, reflecting remarkable invention and transformation over time. Again, this ripple echoes patterns we see in the humanities. At the same time, it also likely reflects the distinctive nature of the faculty in architecture, comprised of professional practitioners who come and go more frequently, infusing the curriculum with new viewpoints and enthusiasms.

content.$t: paragraph-text: Continuity of studio offerings is notable. And yet within courses, titles indicate in-depth specialization, with courses like "Cybernetic Urbanism in the Future London" and "Miami's Little Haiti: a Neighborhood in Transition." This specialization within continuity reflects the case-study nature of studio courses, in which highly-specific sites and subjects are used to support training in basis techniques and perspectives of the practice, from design fiction to site study to drafting., snippet-highlight: 200771,200743

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Continuity of studio offerings is notable. And yet within courses, titles indicate in-depth specialization, with courses like "Cybernetic Urbanism in the Future London" and "Miami's Little Haiti: a Neighborhood in Transition." This specialization within continuity reflects the case-study nature of studio courses, in which highly-specific sites and subjects are used to support training in basis techniques and perspectives of the practice, from design fiction to site study to drafting.

While the humanities aim for experimentation the sciences aim for consistency.

content.$t: paragraph-title: Department Comparison, paragraph-text: In this visualization we can see all once time though classes of all the departments this write-up analysed sorted by the number of one time classes of each department., subline-y-axis: Sorted by departments, data-title: Department Comparison, data-link: ./data/story-two-cultures/classes-only-taught-once-story-selection-sorted.json

content.$t: paragraph-title: All Department Comparison, paragraph-text: Visualized here across departments and fields are all the unique offerings classes: classes which only got taught once at Harvard. Scrolling down, it humanities fields can be spotted by the sheer number and regular distribution of unique offerings over time. We see this signal in hybrid fields, such as Architecture, as discussed above; it's also present in social-science fields, notably Anthropology (some of whose practitioners claim it for the humanities). Another striking signal of novelty and change is found in mathematics, which expresses many unique offerings over time, looking remarkably more like a humanities department than the "sciences" with which it typically is classified, and which depend upon its tools., subline-y-axis: Sorted by departments, data-title: All Departments one time offering, data-link: ./data/story-two-cultures/classes-only-taught-once.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Visualized here across departments and fields are all the unique offerings classes: classes which only got taught once at Harvard. Scrolling down, it humanities fields can be spotted by the sheer number and regular distribution of unique offerings over time. We see this signal in hybrid fields, such as Architecture, as discussed above; it's also present in social-science fields, notably Anthropology (some of whose practitioners claim it for the humanities). Another striking signal of novelty and change is found in mathematics, which expresses many unique offerings over time, looking remarkably more like a humanities department than the "sciences" with which it typically is classified, and which depend upon its tools.

content.$t: paragraph-text: C. P. Snow's thesis was reductive and limited—and damaging to relations among academic disciplines. And yet it's fair to say that the "signal" of two cultures is discernible in the data of course offerings in the sciences and humanities. Whether this observation takes the quality of a scientific law, or the rough-and-ready flexibility of a humanistic interpretation, of course, is open for debate. Terms like "innovation" or "conservatism," which we have used here, are fuzzy— much innovation may happen within the Kuhniam paradigms conserved across course offerings in the sciences, while unique courses offered in any given humanities discipline could be entirely conservative in their content or topics of concern. Perhaps the visualization of these patterns across the disciplines can goad us to reflect on assumptions that are often made about the "two cultures" of the academy, and restore some nuance to reflection on their relations.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: C. P. Snow's thesis was reductive and limited—and damaging to relations among academic disciplines. And yet it's fair to say that the "signal" of two cultures is discernible in the data of course offerings in the sciences and humanities. Whether this observation takes the quality of a scientific law, or the rough-and-ready flexibility of a humanistic interpretation, of course, is open for debate. Terms like "innovation" or "conservatism," which we have used here, are fuzzy— much innovation may happen within the Kuhniam paradigms conserved across course offerings in the sciences, while unique courses offered in any given humanities discipline could be entirely conservative in their content or topics of concern. Perhaps the visualization of these patterns across the disciplines can goad us to reflect on assumptions that are often made about the "two cultures" of the academy, and restore some nuance to reflection on their relations.

content.$t: paragraph-title: A cultural force, paragraph-text: Born as a subculture in the late 1970s in Bronx, New York, hip-hop is firmly rooted in African and African-American cultural expression. It wasn’t until it had become a cultural force in the wider world, however, that scholarly inquiry began to surround it. Hip-hop’s origins and subsequent spread as a global cultural phenomenon make it an ideal subject for interdisciplinary study, but it wasn’t formally offered space in Harvard’s curriculum for over a decade. In the "culture wars" of the 1990s, hip-hop and rap came to the attention of journalists, the wider public—and scholars in music, folklore, and other disciplines. This dawning attention was mirrored, however, in local forces, including the energy of students wrestling with hip-hop's legitimacy and controversial role in society. These forces come together to create a curriculum—and this process is continuous. , subline-y-axis: Sorted by departments, data-title: Search Term: Rap, data-link: ./data/story-hip-hop/rap-full_subjectDescription.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Born as a subculture in the late 1970s in Bronx, New York, hip-hop is firmly rooted in African and African-American cultural expression. It wasn’t until it had become a cultural force in the wider world, however, that scholarly inquiry began to surround it. Hip-hop’s origins and subsequent spread as a global cultural phenomenon make it an ideal subject for interdisciplinary study, but it wasn’t formally offered space in Harvard’s curriculum for over a decade. In the "culture wars" of the 1990s, hip-hop and rap came to the attention of journalists, the wider public—and scholars in music, folklore, and other disciplines. This dawning attention was mirrored, however, in local forces, including the energy of students wrestling with hip-hop's legitimacy and controversial role in society. These forces come together to create a curriculum—and this process is continuous.

paragraph-text: # American Music in the 20th century, snippet-text: The first course at Harvard to mention the word “rap” was Music 218R “American Music in the 20th century” offered by Reinhold Brinkmann. It's notable that this interest arises first not in the Af-Am Department, but in Music.
, snippet-pos: 117766, 1994

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: # American Music in the 20th century

gsx$snippet-text.$t: The first course at Harvard to mention the word “rap” was Music 218R “American Music in the 20th century” offered by Reinhold Brinkmann. It's notable that this interest arises first not in the Af-Am Department, but in Music.

content.$t: image-link: ./data/story-hip-hop/media/rap-flyer-01.jpg, image-subline: “Gangsta Rap” discussion at Harvard in 1994.

paragraph-text: These flyers from 1994 and 1996 give a glimpse into the conversation that was going on on Harvard’s campus at the time. The phrase “gangsta rap” references a subset of hip-hop that became prominent in the 1990s with lyrics that referenced thug lifestyle, gangs, and drug usage. Mounting concerns about explicit violence and misogyny in lyrics and the glorification of gangs, drugs, and weapons led to some resistance towards the genre. Especially as gang violence and crime in black communities became increasingly attributed to the influence of gangsta rap, the issue became impossible to ignore. All of these questions revolve around the intersection of the influence of popular culture.

content.$t: paragraph-text: There is a visible uptick in the amount of courses which mention hip-hop after 2002, the formation of the Hip-Hop Archive. While this correlation isn't self-explanatory, it does point to the ability for specialized institutions to inform other departments and provide avenues for academic inquiry—a correlation that points up the new seriousness given to these forms of expression as culture, heritage, and history.

content.$t: paragraph-text: While African and African American studies comes to have the most courses mentioning hip hop, it remains present in the offerings of other departments. In a comparison between courses which mention rap and hip hop, courses which mention rap decrease after 2005, while courses mentioning hip-hop increase. This simultaneous shift potentially represents a change from studying rap, which conjures diminishing images of richeness is associated more with the lyrics themselves,  to the broader cultural implications of hip-hop as a genre. What constitutes and contributes to a curriculum. , subline-y-axis: Sorted by search terms, data-title: Hip Hop and Rap Comparison, data-link: ./data/story-hip-hop/hip-hop-rap-merge_kind.json

content.$t: paragraph-title: Book History Data, paragraph-text: Although its antecedents stretch back centuries, through philology and antiquarianism, the history of the book emerges as a scholarly field in the middle of the twentieth century, as emerging electronic media inspired scholars to reflect on the technical and material dimensions of communication. Book history brought  a range of existing disciplines and scholarly practices into conversation, attracting the interests of historian, literary scholars, librarians, and archivists, as well as students of new media, graphic design, and visual culture. Its chief impacts in learned discourse and curatorial practice, book history rarely emerges as a department in its own right; its signal in the curriculum may be discovered multi-disciplinarily, by tracing key concepts across fields., subline-y-axis: Sorted by departments, data-title: Search Term: Book History, sorted by departments, data-link: ./data/story-book-history/book-history-data_subjectDescription.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Although its antecedents stretch back centuries, through philology and antiquarianism, the history of the book emerges as a scholarly field in the middle of the twentieth century, as emerging electronic media inspired scholars to reflect on the technical and material dimensions of communication. Book history brought  a range of existing disciplines and scholarly practices into conversation, attracting the interests of historian, literary scholars, librarians, and archivists, as well as students of new media, graphic design, and visual culture. Its chief impacts in learned discourse and curatorial practice, book history rarely emerges as a department in its own right; its signal in the curriculum may be discovered multi-disciplinarily, by tracing key concepts across fields.

content.$t: paragraph-text: If we look for "history-of-the-book," it comes into our data window in the early 1990s as a term in a single course description. It proliferates across courses in a number of fields around 2006-08; this moment coincides with the rise of social media and so-called "Web 2.0" services and sites, a fresh crisis in the sustainability of news media, and the rise of the Google Books project and Kindle and other e-books; these developments kindled fresh interest in book history in public discourse.

content.$t: paragraph-text: Since its inception, book history has been rooted in the lecture mode, typical of lower-division, introductory courses. This is surprising, given the specialized nature of the field., snippet-highlight: 103,778,105,231,110,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Since its inception, book history has been rooted in the lecture mode, typical of lower-division, introductory courses. This is surprising, given the specialized nature of the field.

Throughout, its pattern has been punctuated, appearing in classes that appear and then disappear, or are revived occasionally with many years in between. This is a pattern we see across the humanities as faculty reinterpret terms and concepts for fresh relevance in changing times.

content.$t: paragraph-title: Oral Culture Data, paragraph-text: Delving into some of the field's key concepts helps us widen our understanding of its impact. The concepts of "orality" and oral culture have been key in the worlds of media studies, grammatology, and book history; originating with the rhetoric scholar Walter J. Ong, and inspired by the discovery of traces of preliterate origins of the Homeric epics, the idea of orality arose to explain differences between cultures with a strong basis in writing versus those that communicate and preserve ideas primarily through oral language and other ephemeral means., subline-y-axis: Sorted by learning environments, data-title: Search Term: Oral Culture, sorted by components, data-link: ./data/story-book-history/oral-culture-data_component.json

The concepts of "orality" and oral culture have been key in the worlds of media studies, grammatology, and book history; originating with the rhetoric scholar Walter J. Ong, and inspired by the discovery of traces of preliterate origins of the Homeric epics, the idea of orality arose to explain differences between cultures with a strong basis in writing versus those that communicate and preserve ideas primarily through oral language and other ephemeral means.

content.$t: paragraph-title: Print Culture Data, paragraph-text: Orality's origins in the study of Hellenic literature and the rise of the Greek alphabet are evident in its signal in the curriculum, where it primarily sits in the context of the Classics, with later attention to the brittle literacy of the middle ages, and with an interest, in Education, focused on pedagogical approaches to literate and non-literate cohorts. In comparison, however, the signal of "print culture" is stronger, reflecting perhaps a literate bias that is normative in the intensively-lettristic cultures of the academy., data-title: Search Term: Print Culture, sorted by departments, data-link: ./data/story-book-history/print-culture-data_subjectDescription.json

content.$t: paragraph-title: Oral Culture Data, paragraph-text: And yet, when we filter out language instruction, we find that oral culture and orality occur not only in courses about the material history of language and writing, but in two fields far from the humanities: education and public health. For workers and scholars in these fields, the concept of "oral culture" could prove useful, as both learning and the delivery of care proceed very differently in communities where the oral transmission of knowledge is rich and vital, and may take precedence over official communication in written form. And thus a concept arising in the humanities, in book history and media theory, finds its way into far-flung fields, extending its critical salience., data-title: Search Term: Oral Culture, sorted by departments, data-link: ./data/story-book-history/oral-culture-data_subjectDescription.json

content.$t: paragraph-title: Transcript Stories of Eliot & Stein, paragraph-text: Gertrude Stein and T. S. Eliot: these two iconic figures were near-contemporaries in their student careers at Harvard, giving us a fascinating chance to chart the curricular roots of literary achievement, cultural influence, and curricular entanglement—not to mention varying degrees of gendered opportunity in research, learning, and intellectual ambition among college students around the turn of the last century. And by connecting these transcripts with the signals of Stein and Eliot in the latter-day curriculum, we can suggest some fascinating connections and implications., subline-y-axis: Sorted by departments, data-title: Classes T.S. Eliot attended at Harvard, 1906 – 1909, data-link: ./data/story-stein-eliot/Eliot_subjectDescription.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Gertrude Stein and T. S. Eliot: these two iconic figures were near-contemporaries in their student careers at Harvard, giving us a fascinating chance to chart the curricular roots of literary achievement, cultural influence, and curricular entanglement—not to mention varying degrees of gendered opportunity in research, learning, and intellectual ambition among college students around the turn of the last century. And by connecting these transcripts with the signals of Stein and Eliot in the latter-day curriculum, we can suggest some fascinating connections and implications.

content.$t: image-link: ./data/story-stein-eliot/images/study-card-eliot-low-res.jpg, image-subline: Study card for T. S. Eliot, class of 1910. Harvard University Archives.

gsx$image-subline.$t: Study card for T. S. Eliot, class of 1910. Harvard University Archives.

content.$t: paragraph-title: T.S. Eliots time at Harvard, paragraph-text: It's safe to say that, if you wanted to grow up to author "The Wasteland" and Four Quartets, you could hardly do better than to follow the course of study young Thomas Stearns Eliot. His undergraduate course hewed rigorously, almost exclusively, to languages and literatures. In his freshman and sophomore years, he took courses in French, German, and Greek, adding the history of ancient art and the history of philosophy in his second year. Eliot's history of modern philosophy course, Phil B2, was taught by George Santayana, the famous aphorist, critic of German idealism, and explicator of pragmatism. In his senior year, Eliot would take a second course, philosophy of history, with Santayana as well. Beyond this, Eliot's focus remained rigorously trained on literature and aesthetics as an upperclassmen, with course in English literature in its relation to the continent, tendencies in continental literature of the renaissance, Latin literature, and the history of allegory.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: It's safe to say that, if you wanted to grow up to author "The Wasteland" and Four Quartets, you could hardly do better than to follow the course of study young Thomas Stearns Eliot. His undergraduate course hewed rigorously, almost exclusively, to languages and literatures. In his freshman and sophomore years, he took courses in French, German, and Greek, adding the history of ancient art and the history of philosophy in his second year. Eliot's history of modern philosophy course, Phil B2, was taught by George Santayana, the famous aphorist, critic of German idealism, and explicator of pragmatism. In his senior year, Eliot would take a second course, philosophy of history, with Santayana as well. Beyond this, Eliot's focus remained rigorously trained on literature and aesthetics as an upperclassmen, with course in English literature in its relation to the continent, tendencies in continental literature of the renaissance, Latin literature, and the history of allegory.

content.$t: paragraph-title: T.S. Eliots in todays curricular at the University, paragraph-text: Eliot would pursue a master's degree in the following years, with coursework intensively plumbing histories of ancient religion, adding study of Pali and Sanskrit to his linguistic training. Across graduate and undergraduate coursework, Eliot's focus relentlessly held to the sounds and tropes that would pattern The Wasteland and Prufrock, attracting the staunch support of his champion, Ezra Pound, and setting the standard for a priestly, Apollonian high modernism in twentieth century American letters., data-title: Search Term: T.S. Eliot, 1980 – 2020, data-link: ./data/story-stein-eliot/ts-eliot-1960-2020_subjectDescription.json

gsx$paragraph-title.$t: T.S. Eliots in todays curricular at the University

content.$t: paragraph-text: A century after he completed his studies, Eliot's signal in the curriculum is scarcely wider than his own course of study. Eliot's appearance in courses betokens both his centrality in the modern canon, and the narrowness of his impact and appeal. Beyond a consistent murmur in survey courses in the English Department, Eliot's presence is notable in courses plumbing connections between literature and religion—reflecting the intense focus of his graduate study, and the rigorous, rich, tortured piety of his later work.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: A century after he completed his studies, Eliot's signal in the curriculum is scarcely wider than his own course of study. Eliot's appearance in courses betokens both his centrality in the modern canon, and the narrowness of his impact and appeal. Beyond a consistent murmur in survey courses in the English Department, Eliot's presence is notable in courses plumbing connections between literature and religion—reflecting the intense focus of his graduate study, and the rigorous, rich, tortured piety of his later work.

content.$t: paragraph-text: Beyond canonical literary influence and mystical and devotional writing, Eliot's presence in the curriculum registers mingles the theme of alienation and his Harvard connection with an adventure in performance, in Cecile Guedon's adventuresome course exploring the presence of dance across a spectrum of literary modernity.  This recalls the opening lines of "Burnt Norton" from the Four Quartets:

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Beyond canonical literary influence and mystical and devotional writing, Eliot's presence in the curriculum registers mingles the theme of alienation and his Harvard connection with an adventure in performance, in Cecile Guedon's adventuresome course exploring the presence of dance across a spectrum of literary modernity.  This recalls the opening lines of "Burnt Norton" from the Four Quartets:

content.$t:
paragraph-text: At the still point of the turning world. Neither flesh nor fleshless;
Neither from nor towards; at the still point, there the dance is,
But neither arrest nor movement.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t:
At the still point of the turning world. Neither flesh nor fleshless;
Neither from nor towards; at the still point, there the dance is,
But neither arrest nor movement.

content.$t: paragraph-text: In Eliot's evocation of the flux of dance arrested in a timeless flux, we see perhaps an echo of his own transcript, which revolved so tightly on Logos, the dynamo of language suspended in time.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: In Eliot's evocation of the flux of dance arrested in a timeless flux, we see perhaps an echo of his own transcript, which revolved so tightly on Logos, the dynamo of language suspended in time.

content.$t: paragraph-title: Gertrude Stein, paragraph-text: Radcliffe alumna Gertrude Stein, arrived at Harvard with an unconventional preparatory background and a capacity for idiosyncratic self-advocacy. Under William James's influence, she intended to study medicine after college. Strikingly for a would-be author, Stein's coursework ranged widely across the sciences, with emphasis on biology and psychology. Stein's literary emphasis was minimal, with introductory coursework in German literature and the poetry and prose of France, where she would make her home. With coursework in botany, chemistry, and zoology, however, Stein ranged freely in the sciences of living systems during an era of remarkable advances in medicine and the life sciences. And her avid interest in psychology, with lab work involving extensive wordplay, would be echoed in the oneiric style of her own literary work in decades to come., data-title: Classes Gertrude Stein attended at Harvard, 1893 – 1897, data-link: ./data/story-stein-eliot/Stein_subjectDescription.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Radcliffe alumna Gertrude Stein, arrived at Harvard with an unconventional preparatory background and a capacity for idiosyncratic self-advocacy. Under William James's influence, she intended to study medicine after college. Strikingly for a would-be author, Stein's coursework ranged widely across the sciences, with emphasis on biology and psychology. Stein's literary emphasis was minimal, with introductory coursework in German literature and the poetry and prose of France, where she would make her home. With coursework in botany, chemistry, and zoology, however, Stein ranged freely in the sciences of living systems during an era of remarkable advances in medicine and the life sciences. And her avid interest in psychology, with lab work involving extensive wordplay, would be echoed in the oneiric style of her own literary work in decades to come.

gsx$data-title.$t: Classes Gertrude Stein attended at Harvard, 1893 – 1897

content.$t: paragraph-text: Although nearly twenty years apart, Eliot and Stein shared three professors, notably all in philosophy, all three among Harvard's most famous faculty of the era: Santayana, Josiah Royce, and William James. In Royce's course, she likely encountered the work of Henri Bergson, a later influence. Royce's ambitions included a pragmatic reformulation of metaphysics and a rigorous approach to logic; Santayana, discussed previously, was active as a cultural critic and public intellectual. James's knotty pragmatism, so thoroughly intertwined with psychology, placed meaning, values, and experience on par with physical phenomena in accounts of the natural world. In this sense, Stein's later literary work might be seen as an extension of the idiom of this radical empiricism, even its mirror image: an especially nebulous, rich, and provocative modernism in which, if there are no ideas but in things, then ideas also are things that can bump up against each other promiscuously, productively.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Although nearly twenty years apart, Eliot and Stein shared three professors, notably all in philosophy, all three among Harvard's most famous faculty of the era: Santayana, Josiah Royce, and William James. In Royce's course, she likely encountered the work of Henri Bergson, a later influence. Royce's ambitions included a pragmatic reformulation of metaphysics and a rigorous approach to logic; Santayana, discussed previously, was active as a cultural critic and public intellectual. James's knotty pragmatism, so thoroughly intertwined with psychology, placed meaning, values, and experience on par with physical phenomena in accounts of the natural world. In this sense, Stein's later literary work might be seen as an extension of the idiom of this radical empiricism, even its mirror image: an especially nebulous, rich, and provocative modernism in which, if there are no ideas but in things, then ideas also are things that can bump up against each other promiscuously, productively.

content.$t: paragraph-text: Stein's training as an author, in short, was as unconventional as her oeuvre. And thus it's not surprising that her signal in today's curriculum is idiosyncratic and wide-ranging as well. For we find this student of science and the phenomenal dynamics of the psyche cited in courses about identity and selfhood, about the influence of William James, about the poets of error and the performativity of words and the poetics of error. Stein's thick, textured, stream-of-consciousness writing and her unconventional approach to the tenets of autobiography, with likely roots in the psychology lab, have served as a model for writing unconventional lives, and thus find their way into courses on the expression of ethnicity in literature. The puzzle of identity, the sound and movement of words, the role of experiment and accident—these are Stein's legacy in the curriculum, richly evoking her unconventional education.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Gertrude Stein in the contemporary Harvard curriculum.

content.$t: paragraph-text: In this Lens story, we examine the beginnings of the program in African and African American studies at Harvard. At the time of its founding, black students couldn't see themselves in the faculty, nor did their lived experience or the struggles of their communities robustly figure in the curriculum. Plucky and observant students—and the student body at Harvard in the 60s was as engaged and vigilant as at any time—could pick out a kind of invisible curriculum of African and African American studies, however. As we'll see, Africa and the diaspora of its peoples were present in the curriculum before the founding of AfAm—albeit in ways that reflected dominant white narratives. This began to change in the years before the department was founded, but the transformation was painful and slow—and driven at every point by students., data-title: Founding of AfAm at Harvard,, data-link: ./data/story-af-am-founding/AfAmFounding_subjectDescription.json

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: In this Lens story, we examine the beginnings of the program in African and African American studies at Harvard. At the time of its founding, black students couldn't see themselves in the faculty, nor did their lived experience or the struggles of their communities robustly figure in the curriculum. Plucky and observant students—and the student body at Harvard in the 60s was as engaged and vigilant as at any time—could pick out a kind of invisible curriculum of African and African American studies, however. As we'll see, Africa and the diaspora of its peoples were present in the curriculum before the founding of AfAm—albeit in ways that reflected dominant white narratives. This began to change in the years before the department was founded, but the transformation was painful and slow—and driven at every point by students.

content.$t: paragraph-title: The Pastoral and the Primitive: the curriculum prior to 1964, paragraph-text: Well into the mid-1960s, Africa and its diasporas figured in the curriculum in restricted ways: through antebellum US history, folklore studies, and in anthropology courses that reflected the discipline's colonialist origins. Course like "Primitive Arts and Industries" and "Folksong and Balladry" make passing mention of African and African-American cultural forms; African politics arise as a problem from the outside in a cluster of courses dealing with "Nationalism" as a postcolonial issue. The modern vitality of black cultural life in America and around the world, the decline of American cities due to pervasive racial injustice in housing, education, and other aspects of public life, all have little or no apparent presence in the courses of study offered in the first half of the 1960s.

gsx$paragraph-title.$t: The Pastoral and the Primitive: the curriculum prior to 1964

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Well into the mid-1960s, Africa and its diasporas figured in the curriculum in restricted ways: through antebellum US history, folklore studies, and in anthropology courses that reflected the discipline's colonialist origins. Course like "Primitive Arts and Industries" and "Folksong and Balladry" make passing mention of African and African-American cultural forms; African politics arise as a problem from the outside in a cluster of courses dealing with "Nationalism" as a postcolonial issue. The modern vitality of black cultural life in America and around the world, the decline of American cities due to pervasive racial injustice in housing, education, and other aspects of public life, all have little or no apparent presence in the courses of study offered in the first half of the 1960s.

content.$t: paragraph-text: Among these courses, the one with perhaps the most direct relevance to African-American experience, "History of the South 1790-1865," did not mention slavery or black lives and perspectives at all: "The history of the South is studied with emphasis on its relation to the central theme of American history in the 19th century —the achievement of Union through the development of American nationalism." The invisibility of the black experience in such courses would be come a focus of intense concern among faculty, administrators, and activist students in the years to come.

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: Among these courses, the one with perhaps the most direct relevance to African-American experience, "History of the South 1790-1865," did not mention slavery or black lives and perspectives at all: "The history of the South is studied with emphasis on its relation to the central theme of American history in the 19th century —the achievement of Union through the development of American nationalism." The invisibility of the black experience in such courses would be come a focus of intense concern among faculty, administrators, and activist students in the years to come.

content.$t: paragraph-title: A Surging Tide: change in courses of study before 1969, paragraph-text: As we scan the course catalogs through the 1960s, shifts become apparent in the second half of the decade. History courses not only nod to Africa, but begin to distinguish its patterns of regional and national history. In anthropology and especially in the dynamic Social Relations department, courses are offered that take African cultures not as survivals of some primordial past, but as living entities at work in the modern world. Courses in Government address urban problems, and a selection of African topics open up in the Humanities and Fine Arts as well.

gsx$paragraph-title.$t: A Surging Tide: change in courses of study before 1969

gsx$paragraph-text.$t: As we scan the course catalogs through the 1960s, shifts become apparent in the second half of the decade. History courses not only nod to Africa, but begin to distinguish its patterns of regional and national history. In anthropology and especially in the dynamic Social Relations department, courses are offered that take African cultures not as survivals of some primordial past, but as living entities at work in the modern world. Courses in Government address urban problems, and a selection of African topics open up in the Humanities and Fine Arts as well.

content.$t: paragraph-text: And yet these courses remain in the vernaculars of white power and dominant narratives in the disciplines. Academics struggled across fields, especially in the social sciences and humanities, struggled to fit their norms and paradigms to emergent critiques—which increasingly came not from colleagues, but from the public sphere, and from outspoken students in particular. One measure of this: as the decade progresses, even before a program of African and African-American studies is formulated, a host of novel courses (visualized in green) come and go from year to year, as departments experiment to answer student demands and outside forces alike.

One measure of this: as the decade progresses, even before a program of African and African-American studies is formulated, a host of novel courses (visualized in green) come and go from year to year, as departments experiment to answer student demands and outside forces alike.
